attributes.title: The Correlation Between Extra Curriculars, Stress, and Habits. Are They Hurting or Helping Us?

q1.value: The Correlation Between Extracurriculars, Stress, and Habits. Are They Hurting or Helping Us?

q2.value: Malinda Woody, Amari Whiteside, Coleman Bray

q3.value: Through this study we will be looking at the correlation between stress, extracurricular activities, and procrastination. This study is being done is to determine whether participating in these activities, and thus being busy and engaged, is an effective way to overcome procrastination and to live in a low stress way.  The implications of this study can provide into whether extracurriculars can promote a healthy lifestyle.

q4.value: Being involved in extracurricular activities will have a negative correlation with procrastination and positive correlation with stress.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This will be a correlational design. We will be collecting data from questionnaires of both stress and procrastination as well as the length of time they are in their activities. We will be using Lay’s procrastination scale as well as the Perceived Stress Scale. We will be measuring extracurricular by asking the activities a person is in such as clubs, Greek life, student government, religious groups, and athletics. We will ask about leadership positions as well as how long they have been involved.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
At least 40 undergraduates from Clemson University will participate in this study. Participants will be recruited through email, social media, or word of mouth. All of those involved will be 18 years or older.
The study is online through Qualtrics.

q13.value: At least 40 participants but no more than 120.

q14.value:
We used the software program G* Power to conduct a power analysis.

Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. To do this, we'd need at least 82 participants.

q15.value:
We will plan to collect data for 3 weeks (from 3/5/2020-3/25/20
We will stop data collection at the end of that 3 week period.

question.value:
Dependent Variables: Lay's Procrastination Scale and Perceived Stress Scale
Predictors: Extracurricular activities
We will be correlating extracurricular with stress. We are also correlating extracurriculars with procrastination.

q22.value: Will will exclude participants that have an acquiescent response set.

q3.value:
Most of the time, people hurt other people because they want to harm them. However, sometimes, people hurt others with the ultimate goal of helping them (e.g., punishing children for bad behavior, shoving someone out of the way of an oncoming car). This study seeks to accurately measure such 'prosocially-motivated aggression' and to identify the personality factors that predict it.

The majority of aggression research focuses on aggressive behavior in service of anti-social motives (e.g., Chester, DeWall, & Enjaian, 2019). For example, personality traits such as psychopathy and sadism are positively related to aggression and a general tendency to derive hedonic pleasure from the suffering of others (Moor & Anderson, 2019). Despite this dominant perspective among the literature, other work indicates that people harm others for pro-social reasons, such as defending others from an attacker (e.g., Buffone & Poulin, 2014) or because they believe they are protecting their ingroup (Haslam, Reicher, & Rath, 2008).

This suggests that some instances of aggressive behavior may be driven by pro-social motives. Despite this evidence, no known research has sought to empirically measure prosocially-motivated aggression. The current study seeks to validate a laboratory protocol using the Taylor Aggression Paradigm (Taylor, 1967) for the purposes of better understanding the personality traits and other mechanisms that may play a role in pro-social aggression.

This study will provide the first empirical examination of prosocial aggression using modern day laboratory techniques. The current work also seeks to uncover personality factors that might predict pro-social aggression in order to better inform current theoretical models of aggression and violence, as well as interventions that may be developed in the future. Thus, the proposed study stands to make a major contribution to our understanding of aggressive and altruistic behavior.

A study of this type has not been conducted to our knowledge. As such, we anticipate that this study and those that follow will be able to develop a best-practices model for objectively and ethically examining pro-social aggression. We hope that this study will aid in igniting a dedicated line of research across the social sciences aimed at understanding the various situational, neurological, and dispositional factors that may influence pro-social aggression.

Buffone, A. E. K., & Poulin, M. J. (2014). Empathy, target distress, and neurohormone genes interact to predict aggression for others–even without provocation. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 40(11), 1406-1422.

Chester, D. S., DeWall, C. N., & Enjaian, B. (2019). Sadism and aggressive behavior: Inflicting pain to feel pleasure. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 45(8), 1252-1268.

Moor, L., & Anderson, J. R. (2019). A systematic literature review of the relationship between dark personality traits and antisocial online behaviours. Personality and Individual Differences, 144, 40-55.

Reicher, S., Haslam, S. A., & Rath, R. (2008). Making a virtue of evil: A five‐step social identity model of the development of collective hate. Social and Personality Psychology Compass, 2(3), 1313-1344.

Taylor, S. P. (1967). Aggressive behavior and physiological arousal as a function of provocation and the tendency to inhibit aggression. Journal of Personality, 35(2), 297–310.

q4.value:
Main Hypothesis 1: Prosocial motivation will elicit greater aggression than antisocial motivation.

Main Hypothesis 2: Prosocial motivation will elicit lesser aggression than antisocial motivation.

Then we will examine the factors the correlate with prosocially-motivated aggression:

Secondary Hypothesis 1: Prosocial aggression will be associated with greater aggressive feelings of pleasure than antisocial aggression.

Secondary Hypothesis 2: Prosocial aggression will be positively associated with prosocial personality traits.

Secondary Hypothesis 3: Prosocial aggression will be positively associated with antisocial personality traits.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study will use 2-cell (aggression-type: Antisocial vs. Prosocial) between-participants design. Personality and demographic factors will be tested as between-participants correlates. Study procedures will last 1 hour.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to a 'pro-social' or 'anti-social' aggression condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Data collection has begun, but will not be accessed until the time indicated in this registration.

question.value:
--Design & Duration--
This study will use 2-cell (aggression-type: Antisocial vs. Prosocial) between-participants design. Personality and demographic factors will be tested as between-participants correlates. Study procedures will last 1 hour.

--Participants--
Participants will be volunteers from the PSYC 101 subject pool using the SONA system. PSYC 101 students have a 6 credit research participation requirement. One way to earn these credits is by participating in research similar to the current study. All participants must be at least 18 years of age to participate and will be compensated with 1 credit towards their requirement for class, as we anticipate this study to take up to an hour to complete.


--------------------------------Deception Context------------------------------------
Participants will be informed that this study is part of a broader initiative to make research at VCU more diverse by intentionally recruiting community members from low-income areas. Participants will then be advised that because these community participants are not enrolled in classes that they will be compensated in cash.

-------------------------Aggression Task--------------------
The experimenter will then go on to describe the aggression task as a reaction-time competition against the community-recruited opponent. The experimenter will walk participants through the instructions to complete the aggression task. As in the traditional Taylor Aggression Paradigm, from which this task is based, participants will be asked to compete against an opponent in a series of time-reaction trials where whoever reacts first is the winner (e.g., Bushman & Baumeister, 1998; Taylor, 1967). The "opponent" is fictional, however, as all wins and losses are pre-programmed. Under the guise of making the task more competitive participants will set the volume and duration (on scales of 1-10) of a blast of aversive noise to be delivered to the slower responder prior to each of 24 trials.
The volume/intensity chosen across the task function as a quantitative measure of aggression. All noise levels are set so that, although the noise is unpleasant, no damage to the ears of my participants will occur. The human threshold for damage to the ears is 140 decibels and the noises will be calibrated with a decibel-reading device to ensure that under no conditions can they exceed 105 decibels.
Participants will also be informed that the amount that their opponent in this task gets paid for their participation is tied to participant choices during the task.

--------Prosocial versus Antisocial Aggression Manipulation-----------
In the Prosocial Aggression condition, participants will be informed that each unit of sound blast (1-10) will add $0.20 to their opponent’s final compensation fund with a possible maximum of $50.00. In example, a participant that chooses level 6 ($1.20) across all 25 trials would be made aware that their opponent will receive $30.00 for completing the study.

In the Prosocial Aggression condition, participants will be informed that each unit of sound blast (1-10) will subtract $0.20 from their opponent’s compensation fund which starts at $50.00. In example, a participant that chooses level 4 ($0.80) across all 25 trials would be made aware that their opponent will receive $30.00 for completing the study.

Participants in both conditions will be advised that their choices impact their opponent’s compensation fund regardless of the outcome of each trial in terms of who wins or loses. 


---------------------Questionnaires--------------
Following the Taylor Aggression Paradigm participants will complete a battery of questionnaires via an online survey that assess antisocial personality traits, prosocial personality traits, and affective/motivational states experienced during the aggression task:


-----Antisocial Traits-----
Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire
Comprehensive Assessment of Sadistic Tendencies
Emotion-Based Aggression Scale
Self-Report Psychopathy Scale
Social Dominance Orientation

-----Prosocial Traits-----
Affective and Cognitive Measure of Empathy
Interpersonal Reactivity Index
NEO-FFI Agreeableness Scale
Self-Reported Altruism Scale

-----Affective/Motivational States-----
Aggressive Pleasure Scale
Taylor Aggression Paradigm Motives Scale

q14.value:
An a priori power analysis assuming 80% power, an alpha level of .05, and an effect size of d = .24, suggests that 280 participants should be sufficient to power our statistical tests and accommodate missing data from participants who may not fully complete the study, those who may skip over questionnaires, or those who may fill them out improperly. Furthermore, we expect some participants to withdraw their data from the study once the true nature of the study is revealed during the debriefing process.

Alternatively, this is a new line of scientific inquiry. As such, we anticipate some technical malfunctions may occur until best-practices for this line of work are established (one of the goals of the current study). With this sample size we can not only make powerful claims about our results, but we will collect enough data to account for any missing or withdrawn data in order to preserve the integrity of our subsequent findings.

q15.value: We will collect data from no more than 300 participants.

question.value:
The randomly assigned study condition dictates the instructions given during the TAP such that those who are assigned to the 'antisocial' condition will be told that louder sound blasts will take a greater amount of monetary compensation from their opponent, whereas those in the prosocial condition will be told that louder sound blasts will give greater compensation to their opponent.

Further, provocation will be manipulated as a within-subjects component at the trial level during the TAP.

---------------------Questionnaires--------------
Following the Taylor Aggression Paradigm participants will complete a battery of questionnaires via an online survey that assess antisocial personality traits, prosocial personality traits, and affective/motivational states experienced during the aggression task. The resultant data from these measures will be used to provide test the validity of this new experimental procedure and may be used as covariates in statistical models.

-----Antisocial Traits-----
Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire
Comprehensive Assessment of Sadistic Tendencies
Self-Report Psychopathy Scale
Social Dominance Orientation
Emotion-Based Aggression Scale

-----Prosocial Traits-----
Affective and Cognitive Measure of Empathy
Interpersonal Reactivity Index
NEO-FFI Agreeableness Scale
Self-Reported Altruism Scale

-----Affective/Motivational States-----
Aggressive Pleasure Scale
Taylor Aggression Paradigm Motives Scale

Aggressive behavior scores will be computed by finding the average sound blast intensity and duration setting across all 25 trials. 

Participant scores from the self-report measures will be computed by taking the mean across all items. Some measures (e.g., the Buss-Perry Aggression Scale) will require the reverse-coding of certain items prior to computing the total scores. Further, measures that have various facets to them (e.g., the Hostility subscale of the Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire) will also be computed by finding the mean of the relevant items.

Main hypothesis 1 and main hypothesis 2 will be tested in two ways. First, by using independent-samples t-tests to compare the groups' aggregated aggression levels. Second, by averaging volume and duration settings together within each of the 25 trials and then using multilevel modeling with random intercepts and slopes to model the effect of trial at level 1 and experimental condition at level 2.

Our three secondary hypotheses will be tested in two ways. First, by using moderation analyses to test if the effect of condition on aggression is moderated by each trait. Second, by averaging volume and duration settings together within each of the 25 trials and then using multilevel modeling with random intercepts and slopes to model the effect of trial at level 1 and then at level 2 we would model the effect of condition, each personality trait, and their interaction.

q20.value:
Variables showing right-skew may be subjected to log-transformations.

Some items in the self-report scales (e.g., the Buss-Perry Aggression Questionnaire) will need to be reverse-coded prior to computing participant scores.

q21.value: p-values less than .05, 95% confidence intervals around effect size estimates that do not include 0, and effect size point estimates that are in the predicted direction will be used as support for our inferential tests, all analyses will be two-tailed.

q22.value: Outliers beyond +/-3 standard deviations from the mean on any variable will be Winsorized.

q23.value:
Missingness above and beyond 10% found to be missing completely at random will be treated with multiple imputation.

Missingness of this degree that is not missing completely at random (and thus not appropriate for multiple imputation) will simply be reported as a limitation.

q24.value:
Other exploratory analyses that may be conducted depending on the initial findings of this study include testing for correlates from the battery of questionnaires administered after the aggression paradigm, inclusion of covariates, and for controlling variables of concern in any future analyses. 

Further, we may conduct Latent Profile or k-means cluster analyses in order to gain a better understanding of the motives behind pro-social aggression.

q1.value: Retaining Ignored Information in a Dichotic Listening Paradigm

q3.value: In the attention literature, mind wandering is almost exclusively viewed as an impediment for learning and generally harmful for task-performance (e.g., Schooler, et al., 2014). Mind wandering, however, might be associated with reduced cognitive control and a reduced ability to filter out task-irrelevant information (e.g., Amer et. al, 2016). As such, a potential benefit of mind wandering might be an improved situational awareness and potential to learn about environmental stimuli despite being task-irrelevant; That is, a wandering mind might correspond with wandering attention. The broad aim of this study is to explore this possibility. Here, we specifically look at participants ability to filter out distracting words in a dichotic listening task and their influence on a later memory test.

q4.value: We hypothesize that people who self-report high distraction during the dichotic listening task - construed broadly as distraction from other thoughts - will (a) recall fewer "old" words /  have poorer old/new discrimination and (b) incorrectly report more distractor words as "old" during the recognition memory task / poorer old/distractor discrimination.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Participants will listen to words spoken in both concurrently in both headphones. Their task will be to memorize the words spoken in one ear while ignoring the other (to-be-attended ear will be randomized between participants). 

20 words will be spoken once every two seconds. Words will be randomly chosen from a list of 500 high frequency, single-syllable words. Following the study phase participants will indicate how distracted they were by other thoughts on a scale of 0 (not at all distracted) to 100 (extremely distracted) and then complete the old/new recognition memory phase. The memory test will consist of all 20 studied words, all 20 ignored distractor words and 20 new words.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
150 participants will complete the study on Amazon Mechanical Turk who will be compensate $1.30 for their participation. Mechanical Turk qualifications will be set at 98% approval and greater than 5000 HITs completed. Participants will complete two headphone checks to participate in the study. The first ensures they are using headphones and not speakers, and the second ensures they have the headphones on the right ears. Participants who fail the headphone checks will not be able to move forward in the experiment.

We will exclude participants based on the proportion old words correctly recalled. We will exclude participants whose performance is 2 standard deviations below the group mean. We will also exclude participants who do not complete all the trials and exclude participants whose memory task reaction times indicate they were not completing the task appropriately (extremely fast reaction times less than 200 milliseconds or extremely slow reaction times greater than 5 seconds).

q13.value: We will collect data for 150 participants.

q14.value: We completed two pilot studies (50 participants) using slightly different task parameters to determine the viability of doing dichotic listening on Amazon Mechanical Turk. We estimated that 150 participants would give us 80% power to detect a correlation of .2 between distractor "old" responses and their self-report attention response and a small-to-medium cohen's d (~.3) using a split-half analysis (participants who report greater than 50 / less than 50 on the self-report distraction scale) using one-tailed tests.

question.value:
Memory performance for old, distractor, and new words (proportions of old responses, sensitivity and bias scores).
Self-report distraction on a scale of 0 (not at all distracted) to 100 (extremely distracted)

Will analyze the data using correlations between response proportions (old, distractor, new) and distraction probe responses, correlations between d-prime scores (old/new, old/distractor) and distraction probe responses, both using one-tailed tests
- we predict a negative correlation between correct old responses (d-prime old/new) and probe responses
- we predict a positive correlation between the proportion of distractor words incorrectly identified as "old" and probe responses / d-prime (old/distractor) and probe responses

We will also split participants into two groups based on their probe responses, where anyone reporting greater than 50 are put into the "distracted" group and anyone reporting 50 or less are put into the "not distracted" group. We will use t-tests to test the differences between groups for memory performance.
- we predict fewer correct old responses for the distracted group / better discrimination: larger d-prime (old/new)
- we predict more distractor words will be identified as old for distracted group / poorer discrimination between old and distractor words: smaller d-prime (old/distractor)

q22.value: We will exclude participants based on the proportion old words correctly recalled. We will exclude participants whose performance is 2 standard deviations below the group mean. We will also exclude participants who do not complete all the trials and exclude participants whose memory task reaction times indicate they were not completing the task appropriately (extremely fast reaction times less than 200 milliseconds or extremely slow reaction times greater than 5 seconds).

q24.value: Exploratory analyses include looking for age-related effects (e.g., Amer et. al, 2016)

registration_responses.q1: Retaining Ignored Information in a Dichotic Listening Paradigm
registration_responses.q3: In the attention literature, mind wandering is almost exclusively viewed as an impediment for learning and generally harmful for task-performance (e.g., Schooler, et al., 2014). Mind wandering, however, might be associated with reduced cognitive control and a reduced ability to filter out task-irrelevant information (e.g., Amer et. al, 2016). As such, a potential benefit of mind wandering might be an improved situational awareness and potential to learn about environmental stimuli despite being task-irrelevant; That is, a wandering mind might correspond with wandering attention. The broad aim of this study is to explore this possibility. Here, we specifically look at participants ability to filter out distracting words in a dichotic listening task and their influence on a later memory test.
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesize that people who self-report high distraction during the dichotic listening task - construed broadly as distraction from other thoughts - will (a) recall fewer "old" words /  have poorer old/new discrimination and (b) incorrectly report more distractor words as "old" during the recognition memory task / poorer old/distractor discrimination.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data

We estimated that 150 participants would give us 80% power to detect a correlation of .2 between distractor "old" responses and their self-report attention response and a small-to-medium cohen's d (~.3) using a split-half analysis (participants who report greater than 50 / less than 50 on the self-report distraction scale) using one-tailed tests.

registration_responses.q24: Exploratory analyses include looking for age-related effects (e.g., Amer et. al, 2016)
registration_responses.q8.question:
Participants will listen to words spoken in both concurrently in both headphones. Their task will be to memorize the words spoken in one ear while ignoring the other (to-be-attended ear will be randomized between participants). 

20 words will be spoken once every two seconds. Words will be randomly chosen from a list of 500 high frequency, single-syllable words. Following the study phase participants will indicate how distracted they were by other thoughts on a scale of 0 (not at all distracted) to 100 (extremely distracted) and then complete the old/new recognition memory phase. The memory test will consist of all 20 studied words, all 20 ignored distractor words and 20 new words.
